_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192 has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192 has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                 | Process Chemical                 | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration          Anhydrous Ammonia                  35,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a

unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



Sunview Cold Storage Road 192 operates a commercial cold storage for table grapes in Delano, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:



(10) Storage Rooms

(3) Mini Rooms

(6) Precools

(1) Shipping Dock



The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.



All control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above the machinery rooms. A partial list of system components includes:



North Machinery Room

(1) Reciprocating compressor

(1) Screw compressor

(2) Oil separators

(1) Liquid transfer vessel

(1) Main suction accumulator



South Machinery Room

(1) Screw compressor

(1) Oil separator



Condenser Area

(3) Evaporative condensers



Shipping Dock

(1) Accumulator

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Storage 1

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Storage 2

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Storage 3

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Storage 4

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Storage 5

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Storage 6

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Storage 7

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporat

ors (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Storage 8

(1) Accumulator

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Storage 9

(2) Accumulators

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Storage 10

(1) Accumulator

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Precool 1

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Precool 2

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Precool 3

(1) Accumulator

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Precool 4

(1) Accumulator

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Precool 7

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Precool 8

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Mini Room 1

(1) Accumulator

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Mini Room 2

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



Mini Room 3

(1) Accumulator

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



The flooded system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator mounted behind the bunker wall. From the accumulators, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator.  From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.

The system contains numerous safety dev

ices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. 



An ammonia detection sampling system is installed in each refrigerated area which provides two-minute interval monitoring. The sampling system is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate an audible alarm and strobe. There are three (3) monitoring system locations: 1) Computer Room 2) Shipping and 3) Receiving Area. Furthermore, there is a standalone ammonia sensor in the North Machinery Room which will activate an audible and visual alarm along with the emergency ventilation fan.

The ammonia refrigeration system at Sunview Cold Storage Road 192 consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping.  As such, the refrigeration system at Sunview Cold Storage Road 192 is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192 has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192 facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Managem

ent is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History

The facility does not have a 5-year accident history.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192 has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192 continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192 has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a

responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192 has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192 now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192 employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Sunview Cold Storage - Road 192 will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
